title: Dictionaries
description: Store data in key-value pairs with dictionaries

content.text: Dictionaries store data in key-value pairs. Think of them like a real dictionary: you look up a word (key) to get its definition (value).

content.code:
# Create a dictionary
person = {
    'name': 'Alice',
    'age': 25,
    'city': 'New York'
}

# Access values by key
print(person['name'])  # Alice
print(person['age'])   # 25
print(person['city'])  # New York
content.explanation: Dictionaries use curly braces {}. Each entry is key: value. Access values using square brackets with the key.

content.text: Dictionary keys must be unique and immutable (strings, numbers, tuples). Values can be anything!

content.explanation: Just assign to a key to add or update it. If the key exists, it updates. If not, it adds a new entry.

content.text: Safe way to access values with .get():

content.code:
person = {'name': 'Alice', 'age': 25}

# This crashes if key doesn't exist:
# print(person['city'])  # KeyError!

# Use .get() instead (returns None if not found)
print(person.get('city'))  # None

# Provide a default value
print(person.get('city', 'Unknown'))  # Unknown
print(person.get('name', 'Unknown'))  # Alice
content.explanation: .get(key) returns None if the key doesn't exist. .get(key, default) returns your default value instead.

content.text: Use .get() when you're not sure if a key exists. It's safer than using square brackets!

content.explanation: del removes an item. pop() removes and returns the value. Both will error if the key doesn't exist!
Use 'in' to check if a key exists before accessing it. This prevents errors!

content.code:
person = {'name': 'Alice', 'age': 25, 'city': 'NYC'}

# Get all keys
print(person.keys())    # dict_keys(['name', 'age', 'city'])

# Get all values
print(person.values())  # dict_values(['Alice', 25, 'NYC'])

# Get all key-value pairs
print(person.items())   # dict_items([('name', 'Alice'), ...])

# Number of items
print(len(person))      # 3
content.explanation: .keys() gets all keys, .values() gets all values, .items() gets both as tuples.
Looping over a dict gives you keys. Use .items() to get both key and value in each iteration.

content.text: When looping through dictionaries, .items() is usually what you want - it gives you both key and value!

content.code:
# Dictionary of students
students = {
    'alice': {'age': 20, 'grade': 'A'},
    'bob': {'age': 21, 'grade': 'B'}
}

# Access nested values
print(students['alice']['age'])    # 20
print(students['bob']['grade'])    # B

# Add to nested dict
students['alice']['email'] = 'alice@example.com'
print(students['alice'])
content.explanation: Dictionaries can contain other dictionaries! Access with multiple square brackets.
Dictionary comprehensions: {key: value for item in iterable}. They're concise but powerful!

content.prompt: Create a dictionary representing a book with keys: 'title', 'author', 'year'. Then add a 'pages' key with value 350. Print the dictionary.
content.starter:
# Create the book dictionary

# Add pages

# Print result
content.solution:
# Create the book dictionary
book = {
    'title': 'Python Basics',
    'author': 'John Doe',
    'year': 2024
}

# Add pages
book['pages'] = 350

# Print result
print(book)
content.hint: Create the dict with {} and key: value pairs. Add new items by assigning: book['pages'] = 350

content.text: Perfect! Dictionaries are essential for organizing data. Next, we'll learn about functions - how to package code into reusable pieces!
